comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Wilson's second mother-in-law was Sallie White Bolling (1843-1925): www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=27178834

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: Sarah "Sallie" Spears (White) Bolling was the mother of Edith White Bolling Galt Wilson, who married W. Wilson on December 18, 1915 (see en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edith_Bolling_Galt_Wilson).

comment.author: 35014516@N03
comment._content: pennylrichardsca and B-59:  Thanks for providing Mrs. Bolling's full name.  We'll include it in the description next time we update.

comment.author: 94713864@N08
comment._content: Who is the Mr. Blankenburgh on the photo? I am Chris Blankenburgh, born and living in the Netherlands together with lots of other Blankenburghs. In the city of Utrecht you find three buildings "Blankenburgh", "Klein (Small) Blankenburgh", and "Groot (Great) Blankenburgh" Could anybody tell me more about the Mr. Blankenburgh behind President Wilson? Please mail to blanblot@zonnet.nl. Thank You!

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Looks like that's Rudolph Blankenburg, mayor of Philadelphia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rudolph_Blankenburg

comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: This was game 2 on October 9, 1915 in Philadelphia. Woodrow Wilson became the first U.S. President to attend a World Series game. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1915_World_Series en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baker_Bowl
